section.title: Documenting the Skolt Sami Rule file
xfst vs. twolc
section.p: The Skolt Sami rule file differs from the other languages in being an xfst file, rather than a twolc file (each format have different chapters in the pdf version of the Xerox book). The differences between thesew two formats may be summarised as follows:

ul.li: xfst rules are ordered, whereas twolc rules apply simultaneously
xfst rules stand in a feeding-bleeding relation to each other, whereas twolc rules do not
xfst rules are good at doing many-to-many replacement operations (also of different-size strings), whereas in twolc one must have one rule for each pair of members in equal-length strings
xfst cannot generalise over ordered sets of pairs, thus the Cx:Cy replacement of members of ordered sets Cx and Cy that is found in twolc must be done in a more clumsy way in xfst.

section.p: The reason why xfst is chosen for Skolt Sami (and in the future also for Inari Sami(?)) is that there are several cases of many-to-many replacements in the Skolt Sami grammar.
